Summary Lead Engineer for the industry leader in semiconductor computing products with skills and experience that quickly transfer to engineering innovations across a broad spectrum of industries. An accomplished senior engineer and published researcher with a history of combining academic knowledge with creative engineering process application, strong leadership, and project management skills to successfully deliver results in progressively complex environments such as Intel Corporation and NASA. High-achiever with excellent communication and influencing skills that have led to strategic engineering process changes that exceeded project expectations and requirements. 
 
I believe my rare combination of attributes help me enable companies such that I can uniquely: 
 
•	Drive innovations for the organization with my deep technical background, 
•	Grow the people and organization through leadership and strategic thinking, 
•	and apply my "operational excellence" brand to make the organization run faster, cheaper,  
and more effectively - then continue to add value by creating systems that work. 
 
I invite you to contact me so that I can add value and guide your people and efforts to be successful technically, organizationally, and operationally! Experience Systems Engineering and Integration Lead (Thermal-Mechanical Integration) Intel Corporation April 2014  – Present (1 year 5 months) Hillsboro, Oregon • Leads a rapidly growing team of thermal and mechanical design engineers on cooling solutions for a "high performance computing product" (e.g. supercomputers and unique computing structures). 
 
• Manages systems design integration (including scheduling, planning, and setting and driving technical design strategy) for thermal solutions for product engineering of high performance computing applications. 
 
• Manages and tracks budget for design solutions and relays cost to upper management for financial planning by key decision makers. Performs headcount tracking and projection and provides input to upper management on resource needs. 
 
• Interfaces with extra-departmental teams for cross-functional expertise and systems integration with thermal-mechanical design solutions. Manages relationships with parts suppliers to fabricate design solutions on-time and within budget. Site Leader, Oregon MAPS (Skills-based Volunteering) Intel Corporation May 2012  – Present (3 years 4 months) Hillsboro, Oregon Mentoring and Planning Services (MAPS) coordinator for Oregon and southern Washington. Responsible for building relationships with the executive leadership and "frontline" employees of nonprofit entities. Recruits, selects, and coordinates the activities of volunteer project teams from Intel's vast pool of experts.  
 
Corey has overseen the application of over 1100 professional volunteer service hours (equivalent to >$110,000 in consultation rendered) across 40 Intel volunteers and 18 engagements with the local community. 
 
MAPS is a unique skills-based volunteer program, designed to help Intel employees share their skills, experience, knowledge and expertise with non-profit organizations, educational or governmental, through limited engagement mentoring. Owner, CEO, and Consultant FROSTFIRE TECHNOLOGIES, LLC. November 2011  – Present (3 years 10 months) Texas FROSTFIRETECH's strives to use modeling, simulation, and business process excellence to help our customers predict business operational trends and natural phenomena to enable corporate and academic professionals make key decisions that will reduce time/cost, develop or inmprove products, or perform groundbreaking research. 
 
Current Projects: Providing consulting services for ongoing academic studies in the realm of solid propellant performance modeling.  
 
Aspiring to develop government and commercial relationships to provide scientific and professional services involving modeling, simulation and process-oriented improvements of business and technical systems. Systems Engineering Strategist Intel Corporation May 2013  –  April 2014  (1 year) Hillsboro, Oregon • Driving pathfinding efforts to define and implement systems engineering in quality across the Intel enterprise to increase integration, drive lower cost, and improve development times. 
 
• Program manages product change notification systems with ~1 million notifications per year across 70,000 external customers to drive success in the Intel Customer Excellence Program. 
 
• Developing knowledge transfer systems for design quality issues to be proliferated across multiple product teams. Uses system to ensure design solutions are effectively shared and actions tracked to implementation. 
 
• Manages account with APQC (American Productivity and Quality Center) for benchmarking and process framework analysis to improve business and technical processes. Captures and proliferates learnings through exchange with other senior leaders at partner companies. Operations Manager & Senior Engineering Program Manager Intel Corporation August 2011  –  May 2013  (1 year 10 months) Hillsboro, Oregon • Develops and manages operational improvements for an engineering organization of ~150 direct employees and contract workers and ~$30 million in core resources and funding from other departments. Practices "Kaizen" approach with small innovations that lead to savings in time and effort as well as "bigger idea, bigger risk" contributions that lead to innovative paradigm shifts for the systems, processes, and people of the department. 
 
• Program manages a suite of quality systems for product development utilized across the Intel enterprise and spanning ~100 projects within 18 subprograms (information systems, processes, and governing documentation). Re-imagined program to drive growth to include new customers and business opportunities. Directs and develops a team of business analysts, tech leads, developers, and project managers across 4 company sites in the United States and Costa Rica. 
 
• Improves quality and reliability across the Intel business using Lean Six Sigma methodologies for cross-functional customers. Combines quality methods and principles with technical knowledge to drive strategic improvements, such as aligning department systems and methods to be more effective and efficient. Researcher Petersen Research Group at Texas A&M University August 2008  –  December 2011  (3 years 5 months) College Station, Texas Developed models to predict solid propellant combustion performance (enhanced and anomalous burning trends) with various nanoparticle additive formulations. Integrated models with a high-pressure burning chamber model to simulate thermodynamic effects observed during actual laboratory experiments. Utilized sub-scale and larger-scale tests with specific chemical formulations to validate model predictions. 
 
Designed and built laboratory plumbing systems for high-pressure, high-temperature devices. Produced technical drawings and interfaced with parts manufacturers on cost, supply, and standards issues. 
 
About the Petersen Research Group: (originally at the University of Central Florida in Orlando, FL) Specializing in the study of combustion, gas dynamics and propulsion. We conduct experiments and analyses on reacting flows, chemical kinetics, and shock waves for applications ranging from advanced propellants and rockets to optical diagnostics and gas turbine engines. 
 
Website: http://petersengroup.tamu.edu/index.html Lead Engineer / Project Manager United Space Alliance August 2004  –  August 2011  (7 years 1 month) Houston, Texas Area • Led teams of 15-20 cross-functional, entry-level to senior-level engineers performing engineering design and analysis for 13 safe and successful Space Shuttle missions. Led teams with strong attention to detail and praise-worthy communication practices between the team, government representatives, and other companies. Delivered over 20 presentations at program-level NASA reviews ranging from engineering design and analysis changes to mission status. 
• Supervised the group’s technical and professional performance as the technical group lead. Used best hiring practices to personally recruit, select, train, and mentor new high-performing engineers to lead other design and analysis teams.  
• Identified risks and impacts to shuttle systems as a department representative, team lead, and subject matter expert. Acted accountably for the safety of systems, technical requirements management, and quality of design for multiple project teams. 
• Led a Six-Sigma team that reduced process lead-time for performing engineering design and analysis from 20 to 5 working days. Exceeded NASA officials’ goals to complete analysis within two months and bring the process time down to 1 week. Completed the project a full 4 months before other project teams. 
 
• Applied in-depth knowledge of proprietary models to analyze Space Shuttle abort performance. Used models and knowledge of Space Shuttle systems to assess impacts to performance. Co-developed work-arounds and improvements to models for unique mission situations, system configuration, engineering constraints, and customer requirements.  
• Applied systematic approach to developing and improving the processes, techniques and procedures for the creation of new or substantially improved methods or products for Space Shuttle mission design.
